intro: Ampacus crassinervis, commonly known as the broad-veined Ampacus, is a species of flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its large, showy flowers that range in color from white to pink. Its leaves are broad and have prominent veins, giving it its scientific name. Ampacus crassinervis is often found in wetland or marshy habitats, where it thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils.
